question.text: (CBSE 2023) What is the SI unit of acceleration?
question.explanation: Acceleration = change in velocity/time = (m/s)/s = m/s². Velocity SI unit: m/s. Distance: m.

question.text: (SEBA 2023) A body is said to be in uniform motion if it covers:
question.explanation: Uniform motion: equal distance in equal time intervals, constant velocity. Non-uniform: unequal distances in equal times.

question.text: (CBSE 2022) The distance-time graph for uniform motion is:
question.explanation: Uniform motion: straight line with constant slope (speed). Horizontal line: at rest. Curved: non-uniform motion.

question.text: (SEBA 2022) What does the area under velocity-time graph represent?
question.explanation: Area under v-t graph = displacement (for vector) or distance (for scalar). Slope gives acceleration.

question.text: (CBSE 2021) A car accelerates from rest at 2 m/s². What is its velocity after 5 seconds?
question.explanation: Using v = u + at: u=0, a=2 m/s², t=5 s → v = 0 + 2×5 = 10 m/s.

question.text: (SEBA 2021) Which of the following is a vector quantity?
question.explanation: Vector: magnitude + direction (displacement, velocity, acceleration). Scalar: only magnitude (distance, speed, time).

question.text: (CBSE 2020) The slope of distance-time graph gives:
question.explanation: Slope of d-t graph = speed (for distance) or velocity (for displacement). Slope of v-t graph = acceleration.

question.text: (SEBA 2020) A body thrown vertically upward returns to ground. Its acceleration at highest point is:
question.explanation: At highest point, velocity = 0 but acceleration due to gravity = 9.8 m/s² downward (acting throughout).

question.text: (CBSE 2019) The equations of motion are valid when:
question.explanation: Three equations: v = u + at, s = ut + ½at², v² = u² + 2as. Valid only for constant acceleration.

question.text: (SEBA 2019) A body moving with constant speed in circular path has:
question.explanation: Circular motion: speed constant but direction changes → velocity changes → acceleration (centripetal) present.

question.text: (CBSE 2018) A train moving at 72 km/h comes to rest in 10 seconds. Its retardation is:
question.explanation: u = 72 km/h = 20 m/s, v=0, t=10 s. a = (v-u)/t = (0-20)/10 = -2 m/s² (retardation = 2 m/s²).

question.text: (SEBA 2018) The numerical ratio of displacement to distance is:
question.explanation: Displacement ≤ Distance. Equal for straight line path without change in direction. Less for curved paths.

question.text: Which of the following represents non-uniform acceleration?
question.option: A car moving with constant speed
A car moving in city traffic
question.explanation: Non-uniform acceleration: changing rate of velocity change. Free fall: uniform acceleration (g constant). Constant speed: zero acceleration.

question.text: If a body travels equal distances in equal time intervals, it has:
question.explanation: Equal distances in equal times → constant speed → uniform velocity if direction also constant.

question.text: The velocity-time graph for constant acceleration is:
question.explanation: Constant acceleration: v-t graph is straight line with constant slope. Zero acceleration: horizontal line (constant velocity).

question.text: A body goes from A to B with speed 40 km/h and returns with 60 km/h. Average speed is:
question.explanation: Average speed = total distance/total time. Let distance = d. Time1 = d/40, Time2 = d/60. Avg speed = 2d/(d/40 + d/60) = 48 km/h.

question.text: Displacement can be zero even when distance is not zero. Example:
question.explanation: Displacement zero when initial and final positions same (round trip). Distance covered is path length > 0.

question.text: What is the acceleration of a body moving with uniform velocity?
question.explanation: Uniform velocity → no change in velocity → acceleration = 0. Acceleration = rate of change of velocity.

question.text: A stone dropped from top of a tower reaches ground in 4 seconds. Height of tower is: (g=10 m/s²)
question.option: 160 m Using s = ut + ½gt²: u=0, t=4 s, g=10 m/s² → s = 0 + ½×10×16 = 80 m.

question.text: The motion of a pendulum is:
question.explanation: Pendulum: oscillatory (to-and-fro), periodic. Not uniform (speed changes), not circular (arc path).

question.text: Which equation gives distance in nth second?
question.explanation: Distance in nth second: s_n = u + ½a(2n-1). For u=0, s_n = ½a(2n-1).

question.text: A body moving with initial velocity 5 m/s accelerates at 2 m/s². Distance in 3rd second is:
Rate of change of displacement is:
question.explanation: Velocity = displacement/time (vector). Speed = distance/time (scalar). Acceleration = velocity/time.

question.text: When a body is projected upward, the sign of acceleration due to gravity is taken as:
question.option: Positive or negative depending on position
question.explanation: Upward motion: g opposes motion → negative. Downward motion: g in direction of motion → positive. Convention: downward positive usually.

question.text: A car covers first half distance at 40 km/h, second half at 60 km/h. Average speed is:
question.explanation: Average speed when distances equal = 2v₁v₂/(v₁+v₂) = 2×40×60/(100) = 4800/100 = 48 km/h.

question.text: The motion of Earth around Sun is:
question.explanation: Earth's orbit: approximately circular (actually elliptical). Periodic revolution with nearly constant speed.

question.text: If velocity-time graph is parallel to time axis, then:
question.option: Velocity is zero Displacement is zero Horizontal v-t line: constant velocity → zero acceleration. Slope = acceleration = 0.

question.text: A body starting from rest moves with acceleration 4 m/s². Its velocity after 5 seconds is:
Distance traveled by a body in 2nd second and 3rd second of its motion are in ratio 3:5. Initial velocity is:
A particle moves with constant speed v along a circle of radius r. Its acceleration is:
question.option: Zero Centripetal acceleration = v²/r, directed toward center. Required for circular motion.

question.text: Two balls of different masses are dropped from same height. They will hit ground:
question.option: Depends on shape In vacuum, all bodies fall with same acceleration g (9.8 m/s²) regardless of mass. Air resistance may affect differently.

question.text: The slope of velocity-time graph for uniformly accelerated motion is:
question.option: Decreasing Uniform acceleration → constant slope in v-t graph. Slope = acceleration = constant.

question.text: A body moving with 10 m/s is brought to rest in 2 seconds. Retardation is:
Which of these is NOT an example of periodic motion?
question.option: Heartbeat Periodic motion repeats at regular intervals. Car motion is not necessarily periodic (could be random).

question.text: A train 100 m long crosses a pole in 5 seconds. Its speed is:
question.option: 25 m/s 50 m/s Speed = distance/time = 100 m/5 s = 20 m/s = 72 km/h.

question.text: If displacement-time graph is curved upward, the body has:
question.option: Decreasing velocity Zero acceleration Curve upward (increasing slope) → increasing speed/velocity → positive acceleration.

question.text: The distance covered by a freely falling body in first 3 seconds is: (g=10 m/s²)
